case_name: Ram Kishore and Ramanuj v. Kamal Narayan

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 523 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 523 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 5, 1957 of former Madhya Pradesh High Court at Nagpur in First Appeal No. 112 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 5, 1957 of the former Madhya Pradesh High Court at Nagpur in First Appeal No. 1

facts.text: Dudhadhari Math exists at Raipur in Madhya Pradesh with a temple where idols of Shri Ramchandra, Sita, Laxman, Bharat, Satrughan and Hanumanji worshipped for many years.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-There exists at Raipur in Madhya Pradesh an old Math by the name of Dudhadhari Math within which is a temple where the idols of Shri Ramchandra, Sita, Laxman, Bharat, Satrughan and Hanumanji have been worshipped for very many years.

facts.text: Village Hirmi dedicated by Dinanath Sao for expenses of worship and upkeep of temple.

anchor.surface_text: For the expenses of the worship of the deities and for the upkeep of the temple., one village by the name of Hirmi was dedicated by Dinanath Sao, a wealthy inhabitant of the locality.

facts.text: Main controversy: whether village Telibandha dedicated absolutely to temple by Dinanath or descendants.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytroversy in the present litigation is whether another village of the name of Telibandha which also belonged to Dinanath was dedicated absolutely to the temple either by Dinanath Sao himself or later on by his descendants.

facts.text: Two appellants, descendants of Dinanath Sao, brought suit under s.92 CPC against respondent Kamal Narayan for removal from trustee office of Telibandha and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants, both descendants of Dinanath Sao brought the present suit under s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, for removal of the respondent Kamal Narayan, another descendant of Dinanath Sao, from the office of trustee of the God Shri Ramchandraji Swamy for the village of Telibandha and for accounts.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed Telibandha dedicated to temple in 1857 by Dinanath Sao.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case in the plaint was that Telibandha was dedicated to the temple of Shri Ramchandraji as early as 1857 by Dinanath Sao himself

facts.text: In 1896 partition, descendants reaffirmed dedication of Telibandha by accepting Panchas award.

anchor.surface_text: and later on in the year 1896 when a partition took place between his descendants who were up till that time living jointly, all the companyhares number only re-affirmed the dedication made by Dinanath Sao of this village of Telibandha but themselves dedicated the village Telibandha to the deities in this temple by accepting the award made by the Panchas.

facts.text: Dinanath Sao died in 1862 leaving sons Sobharam and Keshoram.

anchor.surface_text: Dinanath died in 1862, leaving his two sons Sobharam and Keshoram.

facts.text: Partition in 1896 between grandsons of Dinanath.

anchor.surface_text: Sobha Ram had three sons, Sarjoo Prasad, Gokul Prasad and jamna Prasad Keshoram had also three sons, Ramdin, Gajanand and Nand Kishore. At the time of the partition in 1896 Sarjoo Prasad was dead and the parties to the partition were Sarjoo Prasads four sons, Ram Saran Lal, Ramhirde, Ram Krishna and Ramanuj, representing Sarjoo Prasads branch and the other five grand-sons of Dinanath.

facts.text: First appellant Ram Kishore is son of Nand Kishore Sao, second appellant Ramanuj is son of Sarjoo Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant Ram Kishore is the son of Nand Kishore Sao, while thesecond appellant, Ramanuj is Sarojoo Prasads son. The respondent is the son of Ram Saran Lal.

facts.text: By 1896 award, Ram Saran Lal made manager on behalf of deities, no proprietary interest.

anchor.surface_text: By the awardof 1896, it is the plaintiffs case, Ram Saran Lal was number given any proprietary interest in the village Telibandha but was merely made the Manager on behalf of the deities for this property.

facts.text: Ram Saran Lal died in 1930, Kamal Narayan became trustee.

anchor.surface_text: On Ram Saran Lals death in 1930, Kamal Narayan, his son became the trustee.

facts.text: Kamal Narayan committed breaches by sale of lands of Telibandha for Rs. 1,06,774/1/-

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs allege that Kamal Narayan companymitted several breaches of trust by the sale of certain lands of Mouza Telibandha for the sum of Rs. 1,06,774/1/- and in other ways.

facts.text: Plaintiffs petitioned Additional District Judge Raipur under s.3 Charitable Act, directions issued but not complied.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs first approached the Court of the Additional District judge, Raipur with a petition under s. 3 of the Chartiable and Religious Trusts Act for directions on Kamal Narayan as provided in that section. Directions were accordingly issued by the Additional District judge but with this the respondent did number companyply.

facts.text: Suit brought without previous consent of Advocate-General as permitted by s.6 Charitable Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was then that the present suit was brought by the plaintiffs without the previous companysent of the Advocate-General as is permitted by s. 6 of the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act.

facts.text: Defendant denied any dedication of Telibandha.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant denied that Telibandha was ever dedicated.

facts.text: Defendant claimed 1896 award superseded by Bagchi award on May 14, 1898.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the Award of 1896 his plea was that it  lid number express accurately the decision of the Arbitrators an that, in any case, it was superseded by the Award of Mr. Bagchi on May 14, 1898, which was accepted by all the companysharers

facts.text: Trial Court held valid dedication of Telibandha before 1896 confirmed in 1896 award, public trust, breaches by defendant, removed him, appointed Ram Kishore trustee.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the evidence the Trial Court held that there had been a valid dedication in respect of the village Telibandha for the Temple of Shri Ramchandra Swamy. It was number satisfied that the dedication had been made by Dinanath himself but held that there was such a dedication sometime before 1896 and that that dedication was companyfirmed by all the companysharers at the time of the partition of 1896.

facts.text: High Court set aside Trial Court decree, held no absolute dedication proved, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the defendant, the High Court of judicature at Nagpur has set aside the judgment and decree of the Trial Court and ordered the dismissal of the suit. The High Court was of opinion that the dedication of the village Telibandha had number been proved.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal filed on certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision of the High Court the present appeal was filed by the plaintiffs on a certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133  1   b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held absolute dedication of Telibandha by 1896 Panch Faisla award to temple, Ram Saran Lal as manager trustee.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore numberhesitation in holding on a companystruction of paragraph 2 of the Panch Faisala that by this Award Telibandha village was dedicated absolutely to the temple of Shri Ramchandra Swamy and Ramsaran Lal was given possession of it as the manager and trustee of the temple.

facts.text: Bagchi award of May 14, 1896 did not affect validity of 1896 Panch Faisla dedication.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore clearly of opinion that the validity and force of the dedication made by the Panch Faisla has number in any way been affected by the Bagchi Award.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court judgment, remanded for other issues.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, holding that the village Telibandha has been absolutely dedicated to Shri Ramchandra Swamy temple, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and send the case back to the High Court for disposal of the appeal, after deciding the other issues in the suit that require to be decided for its proper disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The question therefore is Does the use of the words Kul haq haquk samet milkiyat ke invariably show an intention to give full and absolute ownership ? We do number think so.

holdings.text: By the 1896 Panch Faisla Award, Telibandha village was dedicated absolutely to the temple of Shri Ramchandra Swamy and Ramsaran Lal was given possession of it as the manager and trustee of the temple.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in holding on a construction of paragraph 2 of the Panch Faisala that by this Award Telibandha village was dedicated absolutely to the temple of Shri Ramchandra Swamy and Ramsaran Lal was given possession of it as the manager and trustee of the temple.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied golden rule of construction, harmonious reading of document, precedents on 'Malik/Milkiyat' as rebuttable presumption, context of purposes, restrictions on alienation, and management show dedication not absolute ownership.

holdings.text: The use of the words 'Kul haq haquq samet milkiyat ke' does not invariably show an intention to give full and absolute ownership.

anchor.surface_text: The question therefore is Does the use of the words Kul haq haquk samet milkiyat ke invariably show an intention to give full and absolute ownership ? We do not think so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption from words rebuttable; must examine whole document, context, circumstances; cited Privy Council and SC precedents emphasizing contextual interpretation over literal.

holdings.text: A partition award can create a valid dedication in favour of a deity under Hindu law if made with the consent of all co-sharers acting as owners.

anchor.surface_text: The act of the Panchas was thus really the act of the owners of the property and as owners had full right to make a valid dedication to the deity the dedication as made in Para. 2 of the Panch Faisla must be held to be valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchas acted on consent and instance of all sharers; equivalent to owners' act; no legal bar under Hindu law.

holdings.text: The Bagchi award of 1896 did not affect the validity or force of the dedication made by the 1896 Panch Faisla.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore clearly of opinion that the validity and force of the dedication made by the Panch Faisla has not in any way been affected by the Bagchi Award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bagchi award not set aside prior award judicially; suit dismissed as compromise without invalidating; no legal infirmity shown in Panch Faisla; Bagchi interpreted prior award without declaring invalidity.

holdings.text: The course of conduct of parties is irrelevant for construction of an unambiguous document.

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court rightly pointed out the course of conduct of the parties is of no relevance for the construction of a document which is itself unambiguous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document (Panch Faisla) clear and unambiguous on its face; construction based on text alone.

holdings.text: The village Telibandha has been absolutely dedicated to Shri Ramchandra Swamy temple.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, holding that the village Telibandha has been absolutely dedicated to Shri Ramchandra Swamy temple, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reiterates primary holding on dedication from construction of 1896 award; reverses High Court.

holdings.text: In case of conflict in a document, earlier disposition of absolute title prevails over later restrictive directions, unless harmonious reading possible.

anchor.surface_text: well settled that in case of such a conflict the earlier disposition of absolute title should prevail and the later directions of disposition should be disregarded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cited precedents; attempt harmonious construction first; if impossible, earlier prevails; applied but context showed no conflict after full reading.

precedents.case_name: Sahebzada Mohd. Kamgar Shah v. Jagdish Chandra Deo Dhabal Deo
precedents.cited_proposition: In case of conflict in a document where an earlier part gives absolute title and later part restricts it, the earlier disposition prevails and later directions are disregarded

precedents.citation: lalit Mohan Singh Roy v. Chukkun Lal Roy  1 [1897 L.R. 24 I.A. 76]

anchor.surface_text: In lalit Mohan Singh Roy v. Chukkun Lal Roy  1  where the words of the gift to the appellant were shall become owner  Malik  of all my estates and properties, it was held that they were sufficient to convey a heritable and alienable estate

precedents.case_name: Lalit Mohan Singh Roy v. Chukkun Lal Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: Words 'shall become owner (Malik)' convey heritable and alienable estate unless context indicates different meaning
precedents.cited_holding: they were sufficient to convey a heritable and alienable estate-unless the context indicated a different meaning

precedents.citation: Surajmani v. Rabi Nath Ojha  2 [1907 L.R. 35 I.A. 17]

anchor.surface_text: In Surajmani v. Rabi Nath Ojha  2  also the use of the word Malik was held to import full proprietary rights, unless there is something in the context to qualify it. In Saraju Bala Devi v. Jyotirmoyee Devi  3  the Privy Council had to conside

precedents.cited_proposition: Use of the word 'Malik' imports full proprietary rights unless context qualifies it

precedents.citation: Saraju Bala Devi v. Jyotirmoyee Devi  3 [1931 L.R. 58 I.A 270]

anchor.surface_text: In Saraju Bala Devi v. Jyotirmoyee Devi  3  the Privy Council had to consider the nature of the  1   1897  L.R. 24 I.A. 76.  2   1907  L.R. 35 I.A. 17.  3   1931  L.R. 58 I.A 270, interest that passed by two leases which constituted the lessee the Malik

precedents.case_name: Saraju Bala Devi v. Jyotirmoyee Devi
precedents.cited_proposition: Lessee constituted 'Malik' of property; context examined and held to confer absolute estate
precedents.cited_holding: the conditions taken singly or collectively did not cut down the absolute estate

precedents.citation: Mohamed Shumsool v. Shewukram   1 [1874 L R. 2 I.A. 7]

anchor.surface_text: This was quite in line with what had been decided in one of the earliest cases- Mohamed Shumsool v. Shewukram   1  where the word Malik came up for consideration. In that case the question arose whether a, testator in saying that only Mst. Rani Dhan Kowar,

precedents.cited_proposition: Word 'Malik' does not always confer absolute estate; context and Hindu notions considered to limit to life estate
precedents.cited_holding: the widow of his son should not take an absolute estate which she should have power to dispose of absolutely, but that she took an estate subject to her daughters succeeding her

precedents.citation: Rai Bajrang Bahadur Singh v. Thakurain Bakhtrai Kuer  1 [1953 S.C.R. 232]

anchor.surface_text: In Rai Bajrang Bahadur Singh v. Thakurain Bakhtrai Kuer  1  this Court had to consider a will which used the words Malik Kamil and Naslan bad naslan in reference to the interest given to the younger son Dhuj Singh. Mukherjea,J., speaking for the Court said-

precedents.case_name: Rai Bajrang Bahadur Singh v. Thakurain Bakhtrai Kuer
precedents.cited_proposition: Words like 'Malik' connote full proprietary rights unless context or circumstances indicate otherwise; applies to construction of documents generally
precedents.cited_holding: where the restrictions are the primary things which the testator desires and they are consistent with the whole tenor of the will, it is a material circumstance to be relied upon for displacing the presumption of absolute ownership implied in the use of the word malik

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, holding that the village Telibandha has been absolutely dedicated to Shri Ramchandra Swamy temple, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and send the case back to the High Court for disposal of the appeal, after deciding the other issues in the suit that require to be decided for its proper disposal.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in holding on a construction of paragraph 2 of the Panch Faisala that by this Award Telibandha village was dedicated absolutely to the temple of Shri Ramchandra Swamy and Ramsaran Lal was given possession of it as the manager and trustee of the temple.

Accordingly, we allow the appeal, holding that the village Telibandha has been absolutely dedicated to Shri Ramchandra Swamy temple, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and send the case back to the High Court for disposal of the appeal, after deciding the other issues in the suit that require to be decided for its proper disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The question therefore is Does the use of the words Kul haq haquk samet milkiyat ke invariably show an intention to give full and absolute ownership ? We do not think so.

anchor.surface_text: The act of the Panchas was thus really the act of the owners of the property and as owners had full right to make a valid dedication to the deity the dedication as made in Para. 2 of the Panch Faisla must be held to be valid.

Accordingly, we allow the appeal, holding that the village Telibandha has been absolutely dedicated to Shri Ramchandra Swamy temple, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and send the case back to the High Court for disposal of the appeal, after deciding the other issues in the suit that require to be decided for its proper disposal.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore clearly of opinion that the validity and force of the dedication made by the Panch Faisla has not in any way been affected by the Bagchi Award.

Accordingly, we allow the appeal, holding that the village Telibandha has been absolutely dedicated to Shri Ramchandra Swamy temple, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and send the case back to the High Court for disposal of the appeal, after deciding the other issues in the suit that require to be decided for its proper disposal.
